DOCUMENT TYPE: Board Meeting Minutes
DATE: January 6, 2025
PREPARED BY: Corporate Secretary Maria Fuentes
DISTRIBUTION: Board of Directors
CLASSIFICATION: Board Confidential
REFERENCE: NXS-BOD-2025-001

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
MINUTES OF THE REGULAR MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Q4 2024 REVIEW AND 2025 OPERATING PLAN APPROVAL

Meeting Location: Nextera Solutions Headquarters, 14th Floor Boardroom, 655 Montgomery Street, San Francisco, California 94111

Meeting Called to Order: 9:02 AM Pacific Standard Time

Members Present:
  Robert Kessler, Board Chair
  David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer
  Sarah Jiang, Independent Director
  Tom Whitfield, Independent Director
  Nina Patel, Independent Director

Also Present:
  Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer (presenting)
  Maria Fuentes, Corporate Secretary (recording)

Quorum: Confirmed. All five members of the Board of Directors were present in person. A quorum existed throughout the entirety of the meeting.

Meeting Duration: 2 hours 14 minutes

---

I. CALL TO ORDER AND APPROVAL OF PRIOR MINUTES

Board Chair Robert Kessler called the meeting to order at 9:02 AM. Mr. Kessler confirmed attendance and the presence of a quorum. The minutes from the October 14, 2024 regular meeting were presented for approval. Mr. Kessler noted that one minor correction had been submitted by Ms. Jiang regarding the phrasing of a resolution on the equity incentive plan amendment; the correction was noted and incorporated into the final version of the October minutes. Upon motion by Ms. Patel, seconded by Mr. Whitfield, the Board unanimously approved the prior meeting minutes as amended.

Mr. Kessler welcomed the Board to the first meeting of 2025 and noted the packed agenda covering Q4 performance review, financial position, the 2025 Operating Plan, governance matters, and the executive session. He proposed proceeding with Mr. Aldric's Q4 review, followed by Ms. Vasquez's financial report, before moving to the operating plan vote. The Board agreed to the proposed order of proceedings.

II. CEO REPORT — Q4 2024 PERFORMANCE REVIEW

Mr. Aldric presented the Q4 2024 performance review to the Board. The presentation consisted of 34 slides covering revenue performance, customer acquisition, competitive dynamics, product milestones, and operational highlights for the quarter ending December 31, 2024. A printed copy of the slide deck was distributed to each Board member.

Mr. Aldric reported that Q4 revenue came in at $31.2M against a target of $30.5M, representing a beat of approximately 2.3% over plan. He noted that the outperformance was driven by three large enterprise deals that closed in the final two weeks of December, each above $250K in annual contract value. Mr. Aldric walked the Board through the customer acquisition funnel, noting that the enterprise pipeline had been strong throughout Q4 with particular strength in the transportation and logistics vertical.

Mr. Aldric: "We closed 14 new enterprise logos in Q4, bringing our total customer count to 218. Net revenue retention is 119%."

He then discussed the composition of the customer base by segment. Of the 218 total customers, 82 were classified as enterprise (greater than $100K ACV), 94 as mid-market ($25K-$100K ACV), and 42 as emerging ($10K-$25K ACV). Mr. Aldric noted that the enterprise segment had grown from 68 customers at the start of Q4, representing a net addition of 14 new enterprise logos during the quarter.

Mr. Aldric reviewed the product roadmap milestones achieved in Q4. The recommendation engine v2.4 release shipped on schedule in October and had been adopted by 34% of the customer base by end of quarter. The supply chain analytics dashboard received a significant update in November with new predictive capabilities that had contributed to several competitive wins. The API gateway was upgraded in December to support higher throughput requirements from the largest customers.

Ms. Jiang asked about the company's competitive positioning in the mid-market segment, specifically against Palantir, which had been increasing its presence in deals under $500K ACV.

Ms. Jiang: "What is our win rate against Palantir in deals under $500K ACV?"

Mr. Aldric: "Approximately 62% in that segment, up from 54% in Q3."

Mr. Aldric elaborated that the win rate improvement was driven by the deployment of the recommendation engine v2 release in October, which had been well received by mid-market prospects during proof-of-concept evaluations. He provided examples of two competitive displacements in Q4 where the recommendation engine functionality was a deciding factor in the customer's vendor selection process. He noted that Palantir's pricing in the sub-$500K segment had become more aggressive in Q4, but that Nextera's product differentiation — specifically real-time supply chain visibility and the recommendation engine's ability to process multi-modal logistics data — continued to be the primary win driver.

Mr. Whitfield asked about gross margin trends and whether the competitive pricing pressure from Palantir had required any discounting that might affect margins. Ms. Vasquez responded that gross margin for Q4 was 78.3%, in line with the trailing four-quarter average of 78.1%. She noted that average selling price had remained stable and that the handful of deals where competitive discounting had been applied were offset by strong expansion pricing within the existing customer base. She noted that professional services revenue had been stable and that the gross margin reflected an increasing mix of subscription revenue relative to professional services.

Ms. Patel asked about customer churn in Q4. Mr. Aldric responded that gross revenue retention was 94% on a trailing twelve-month basis, with two small customer losses in Q4 totaling approximately $180K in ARR. Both losses were attributed to the customers' own business closures rather than competitive displacement or product dissatisfaction.

III. CFO REPORT — FINANCIAL POSITION

Ms. Vasquez presented the financial position of the company as of December 31, 2024. The presentation included audited balance sheet data, cash flow statements, and key financial metrics. The following highlights were reported:

Cash and Cash Equivalents: $28.4M
Short-term Investments: $0 (all cash held in operating and money market accounts)
Credit Facility: $15M revolving credit facility with Silicon Valley Bank, currently undrawn
Total Debt: None (the company has no term debt outstanding)
Accounts Receivable: $14.2M (Days Sales Outstanding: 42 days)
Accounts Payable: $4.8M
Deferred Revenue: $22.8M
Total Stockholders' Equity: $62.4M

Ms. Vasquez noted that the company's cash position remained strong and that the operating plan for FY2025 did not contemplate the need for additional equity or debt financing. She stated that at the current burn rate, the company had approximately 24 months of runway. She noted that the credit facility with Silicon Valley Bank was available as a backstop but that management did not anticipate drawing on it.

Q4 2024 ARR: $118.7M, up from $104.2M at Q4 2023, representing approximately 14% year-over-year growth. Ms. Vasquez walked through the quarterly cash flow statement, noting that Q4 free cash flow was approximately negative $1.0M, an improvement from negative $2.1M in Q3 and negative $3.4M in Q2. She attributed the improvement to operating leverage as revenue scaled while headcount growth was held to planned levels.

Ms. Vasquez presented a summary of working capital metrics. The company's current ratio was 2.8:1, reflecting a strong liquidity position. She noted that the deferred revenue balance of $22.8M was the highest in the company's history and reflected the shift toward annual and multi-year prepaid contracts in the enterprise segment.

Mr. Kessler asked about the interest rate on the revolving credit facility. Ms. Vasquez responded that the facility carried SOFR plus 175 basis points, with an annual commitment fee of 25 basis points on undrawn amounts. The facility was set to mature in June 2026 and management planned to renew on similar terms.

IV. 2025 OPERATING PLAN

Mr. Aldric presented the 2025 Operating Plan for Board approval. The presentation was 42 slides, covering financial targets, headcount plan, product roadmap, go-to-market strategy, infrastructure investments, and risk factors. A bound copy of the full operating plan document was distributed to each Board member.

Key elements of the 2025 Operating Plan:

Revenue Target: $142M ARR by December 31, 2025 (approximately 20% YoY growth)
Headcount: Increase from 402 to 465 FTEs
New Logo Target: 50+ enterprise customers
Gross Margin Target: 78-80%
EBITDA Target: Breakeven by Q4 2025
Total Operating Budget: $108.6M
Capital Expenditures: $12.6M

Mr. Aldric walked through the revenue build, starting from the $118.7M ARR base and adding planned new logo acquisition, expansion, and accounting for expected churn. He noted that the plan assumed a conservative churn rate of approximately 5% and that the $142M target required approximately $28M in net new ARR through a combination of new logos and expansion within the installed base.

The Board discussed the plan at length. Ms. Patel inquired about the assumptions underlying the headcount increase, specifically the split between revenue-generating roles and support functions. Mr. Aldric noted that approximately 40% of the net new hires would be in Engineering (approximately 25 positions), 30% in Sales (approximately 19 positions), and the remainder split across Customer Success, Product, and G&A functions.

Mr. Whitfield asked about the product roadmap's major bets for 2025. Mr. Aldric noted three key initiatives: the recommendation engine v3 general availability release (targeted for February 2025), the supply chain dashboard redesign (targeted for March), and a potential data partnership with Axion Labs that was in the evaluation phase. He emphasized that the roadmap was designed to strengthen the company's competitive position in the enterprise segment while expanding into adjacent use cases.

Mr. Kessler asked about the capital expenditure assumptions in the plan. Ms. Vasquez responded that the $12.6M capex budget was primarily allocated to infrastructure migration — the Kubernetes project — at approximately $5.8M, office expansion at $3.2M (15th floor buildout and furniture), and the remainder split across lab equipment, testing infrastructure, and miscellaneous IT capital.

Ms. Jiang asked about the competitive landscape assumptions in the plan. Mr. Aldric noted that the plan assumed continued pricing pressure from Palantir in the mid-market and potential new entrants in the supply chain intelligence space, but that Nextera's product differentiation and net revenue retention metrics provided a strong defensive moat.

Board unanimously approves 2025 operating plan with $142M revenue target.

RESOLVED: The Board approves the 2025 Operating Plan as presented, with authorized headcount increase from 402 to 465 FTEs.

Upon motion by Mr. Whitfield, seconded by Ms. Jiang, the resolution was adopted unanimously with all five Board members voting in favor. The Corporate Secretary recorded the vote.

V. GOVERNANCE MATTERS

Mr. Kessler motioned to ratify the appointment of two new independent auditors to supplement the existing Ernst & Young engagement for the FY2024 annual audit. The two additional auditors, Margaret Wu, CPA, and Samuel Greenbaum, CPA, were recommended by the Audit Committee following a review of their qualifications and independence. The Audit Committee had confirmed that neither Ms. Wu nor Mr. Greenbaum had any conflicts of interest or material relationships with the company.

Mr. Kessler noted that the additional auditors were brought on to support the expanded scope of the FY2024 audit, which included new revenue recognition procedures and the initial assessment of the company's internal controls in anticipation of potential future reporting requirements. He stated that the Audit Committee had thoroughly vetted both candidates and was satisfied with their qualifications.

Upon motion by Mr. Kessler, seconded by Ms. Patel, the Board unanimously ratified the appointments.

Ms. Fuentes presented the upcoming Board calendar for review:
  - February 10, 2025: Regular meeting (January financial review)
  - April 14, 2025: Regular meeting (Q1 2025 review)
  - June 9, 2025: Annual meeting of stockholders
  - July 14, 2025: Regular meeting (Q2 2025 review)
  - October 13, 2025: Regular meeting (Q3 2025 review)

The Board confirmed the calendar as presented. Mr. Kessler noted that the next Board meeting was scheduled for February 10, 2025, at which time the Board would receive the January financial update and a progress report on the 2025 Operating Plan.

VI. EXECUTIVE SESSION

At 10:45 AM, the Board entered executive session with only independent directors and the CEO present. The Corporate Secretary was excused from the executive session. The executive session lasted approximately 30 minutes. No formal actions were taken during the executive session.

VII. ADJOURNMENT

There being no further business, upon motion by Ms. Jiang, seconded by Mr. Whitfield, the meeting was adjourned at 11:16 AM Pacific Standard Time.

Respectfully submitted,

Maria Fuentes
Corporate Secretary
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

APPROVED: ___________________________
Robert Kessler, Board Chair
Date: _______________________________

Attachments:
  Exhibit A: Q4 2024 Performance Review Presentation (34 slides)
  Exhibit B: Financial Position Summary
  Exhibit C: 2025 Operating Plan (42 slides)
  Exhibit D: Auditor Independence Certifications

---

DOCUMENT TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: January 6, 2025
FROM: Priya Vasquez (CFO)
TO: Finance Team All
SUBJECT: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Finance

--- Original Message ---
From: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
To: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 11:32 AM PST
Subject: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Team,

Happy New Year. I hope everyone had a restful break.

With the board meeting behind us this morning, the 2025 Operating Plan is now officially approved. That means we need to move quickly on finalizing all departmental budgets and locking in our vendor renewal schedule for the year.

Here is where we are and what I need from each of you:

TOTAL FY2025 OPERATING BUDGET: $108.6M

Breakdown by department:
  R&D: $42.1M (38.8% of total operating budget)
  Sales & Marketing: $35.7M
  General & Administrative: $18.2M
  Capital Expenditures: $12.6M

Please ensure all department heads have signed off on their allocated budgets by January 15. No exceptions.

I've attached the departmental budget templates in the shared drive at Finance > FY2025 > Departmental Budgets. Each department head needs to review, approve, and sign the electronic form in DocuSign. Jordan has set up the routing — once a department head signs, it will automatically route to me for final approval.

Action Items:

1. Jordan — the vendor renewal schedule needs to reflect our standard 24-36 month commitment cycles. Let's lock that down before the board package goes out. I need the finalized vendor renewal schedule by January 17. We have 47 contracts up for renewal in FY2025, and I want to make sure we're capturing all early renewal discounts and avoiding any auto-renewal surprises. Please also flag any contracts where we have termination for convenience clauses that could give us leverage in renewal negotiations.

2. Angela — please verify the audit preparation timeline with Ernst & Young. I want to make sure we are aligned on their March window and that all Q4 revenue recognition is buttoned up. Also, please update the intercompany reconciliation for our UK subsidiary — it was flagged as an open item in the November close.

3. Derek — I need you to build the quarterly revenue waterfall model. This should show our path from $118.7M ARR to the $142M target, broken down by new logo, expansion, and churn. I'd like to review a first draft by January 13. Please pull the pipeline data from Salesforce and use last year's conversion rates as the starting assumption.

A few additional notes:

The R&D budget increase reflects the approved headcount plan. Marcus is planning to add 26 engineers in the first half, so we need to phase the hiring expense correctly in the waterfall. We should assume a 45-day ramp for new engineers before they're fully productive and billing to projects.

The S&M budget includes the expanded President's Club program that Kevin requested. I've allocated $200K for the trip plus an additional $150K in SPIFs for Q1 pipeline acceleration. Kevin's team is targeting 10 new enterprise logos in Q1 and the SPIFs are designed to accelerate proof-of-concept cycles.

G&A includes the additional office space we're leasing on the 15th floor. The lease terms are being finalized by Rachel's team. Expected occupancy is March 1. The buildout cost ($3.2M) is in the capex budget, and the annual lease expense ($680K) is in the G&A budget.

One more thing — I'd like to schedule our annual planning offsite for the Finance team. Last year we did Big Sur and it was great. Let's aim for the first week of February. Jordan, can you look into availability at Post Ranch Inn or Ventana? Budget is $3K per person for the two-night stay.

Let me know if you have questions. Let's have a quick sync tomorrow at 10 AM to walk through the open items.

Priya

--- Reply ---
From: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 12:14 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

Happy New Year to you too. Thanks for the recap.

I've already started pulling the vendor renewal data from the procurement system. I have 43 of the 47 contracts mapped to renewal dates — the remaining 4 are legacy agreements that don't have structured renewal terms in the system. I'll chase those down this week.

Quick question on the AWS renewal: we locked in the 3-year commitment last week at the 8% discount. Should I count that as done or do we need formal sign-off from the board given it exceeds the $4M threshold? The total commitment value is approximately $11.3M over 3 years.

On the offsite — Post Ranch has availability Feb 3-5. Ventana is fully booked that week but has Feb 10-12 open. Let me know your preference and I'll hold the rooms.

I'll have the full vendor renewal schedule ready by the 17th.

Jordan

--- Reply ---
From: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
To: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 12:28 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Jordan,

Good catch on the AWS threshold. The board pre-authorized all infrastructure commitments within the approved capex budget at this morning's meeting, so we're covered. Mark it as approved. Please file the board authorization reference (Resolution 2025-001) in the contract file.

For the 4 legacy contracts — if they're under $50K annual, let's just bring them into the standard renewal template at their next renewal date. If any are over $50K, flag them for me and I'll work with Rachel's team on structuring proper MSAs.

Let's go with Post Ranch Feb 3-5. Book it.

Priya

--- Reply ---
From: Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
To: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 1:45 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

I spoke with our E&Y partner, Samantha Reeves, this morning. They've confirmed the March 3-21 audit window. Their team will be on-site the first week (March 3-7) for walkthroughs and testing, then remote for the remainder.

I've verified that all Q4 revenue recognition is complete. We had two items that required judgment calls — a multi-year prepaid deal with TransGlobal Shipping and a usage-based component for FreshTrack Logistics. Both have been documented per ASC 606 and reviewed by Samantha's team in their pre-audit call last month. I have the memo files ready for the PBC list.

I'm preparing the PBC (Prepared by Client) list and will have it distributed to all department leads by January 20 with responses due February 14. The PBC includes 87 items this year, up from 72 last year due to the expanded scope Mr. Kessler mentioned.

The UK subsidiary intercompany recon is in progress — I expect to close it out by end of this week. The only open item is a $47K timing difference on a cross-border software license payment that straddled the quarter end. It's straightforward but needs documentation.

Angela

--- Reply ---
From: Derek Hollis <d.hollis@nextera.io>
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 2:30 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

I'll have the revenue waterfall draft ready by the 13th. Quick initial cut: to get from $118.7M to $142M, we need roughly $28M in net new ARR, assuming approximately $5M in gross churn. That implies about $33M in gross new business (new logos plus expansion) offset by churn.

Based on Kevin's pipeline numbers and our historical conversion rates, I'm modeling:
  - New logo ARR: ~$19M (50+ logos at ~$380K blended ACV)
  - Expansion ARR: ~$14M (based on 119% NRR applied to expanding cohorts)
  - Gross churn: ~$5M (6% gross on the ~$80M expansion-eligible base)
  - Net new ARR: ~$28M

I'll layer in the quarterly phasing based on last year's seasonality patterns. Q1 is typically our softest quarter (approximately 18% of annual bookings), so I'll weight accordingly. Q4 is usually the strongest at about 32%, with Q2 and Q3 splitting the remainder roughly evenly.

I'm also building a sensitivity analysis showing the impact of plus or minus 5% on each variable. I'll include scenarios for faster-than-expected churn and slower-than-expected new logo acquisition so we have the board package ready for the February meeting.

One question: should I model the Axion Labs partnership impact separately? Hannah mentioned it in the product roadmap and it could drive incremental expansion revenue if it lands. I don't want to bake it into the base case but could show it as an upside scenario.

Derek

---

Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone.

DOCUMENT TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: January 9, 2025
FROM: Marcus Webb, VP Engineering
TO: Engineering All
SUBJECT: Platform Migration Update — Kubernetes 1.29
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Engineering
REFERENCE: ENG-2025-MIG-002

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — ENGINEERING
Platform Migration Update: Kubernetes 1.29

To: All Engineering
From: Marcus Webb, VP Engineering
Date: January 9, 2025

Team,

I'm writing to give you a comprehensive update on our Kubernetes 1.29 migration project, which is a key initiative for Q1 2025.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Phase 1 is done. Staging is running clean on K8s 1.29. Lisa's team will begin production migration February 3. Plan for a 4-hour maintenance window on February 5.

PHASE 1 COMPLETION — STAGING ENVIRONMENT

Lisa Chen and the platform team completed the staging environment migration over the holiday break. The staging cluster is now fully running on Kubernetes 1.29 on our AWS EKS infrastructure. Key results from the staging migration:

  - All 47 microservices migrated successfully
  - Zero downtime during the migration process
  - All automated tests passing (integration, load, and smoke tests)
  - Datadog monitoring dashboards have been updated to reflect the new architecture
  - No rollback was required at any point during the migration

Load test results are particularly encouraging. Lisa's team has been running load tests at 2x peak traffic levels on the staging environment over the past week.

Load test results: p99 latency at 2x traffic is 340ms, well within our 500ms SLA.

Detailed load test metrics:
  - Concurrent connections tested: 15,000
  - Sustained throughput: 8,400 requests/second
  - p50 latency: 45ms
  - p95 latency: 190ms
  - p99 latency: 340ms
  - Error rate: 0.003%
  - Test duration: 4 hours continuous
  - CPU utilization at peak: 72%
  - Memory utilization at peak: 64%

The full load test report is available in Confluence: [K8s 1.29 Load Test Results](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/k8s-129-loadtest)

CURRENT INFRASTRUCTURE

For context, here's what our current production infrastructure looks like:

  - 94 EC2 instances across 3 AWS regions (us-west-2, us-east-1, eu-west-1)
  - 47 microservices
  - Primary region: us-west-2 (Portland, OR) — hosts 52 instances
  - Secondary region: us-east-1 (N. Virginia) — hosts 28 instances
  - DR region: eu-west-1 (Ireland) — hosts 14 instances
  - Total monthly infrastructure cost: approximately $185K/month
  - Target: 60% cost reduction through containerization (to approximately $74K/month)

The cost savings from containerization are significant. At $185K/month, we're spending $2.22M annually on infrastructure. A 60% reduction would save approximately $1.33M per year. This is one of the highest-ROI projects in the engineering portfolio.

PRODUCTION MIGRATION PLAN

Production migration is scheduled for February 3-7, with the following timeline:

  February 3 (Monday): Begin migration of stateless API services
    - Services affected: 12 API gateway services, 8 authentication services
    - Expected duration: 8 hours
    - Zero-downtime deployment using blue-green strategy

  February 4 (Tuesday): Migrate worker and queue services
    - Services affected: 15 background workers, 4 queue processors
    - Expected duration: 6 hours
    - Queue draining will be coordinated with on-call team

  February 5 (Wednesday): Main migration window — stateful services, databases, caches
    - Maintenance window: 2:00 AM - 6:00 AM Pacific
    - Customer-facing APIs unavailable during this period
    - Database migration includes PostgreSQL failover and Redis cluster reconfiguration
    - This is the highest-risk portion of the migration

  February 6 (Thursday): Post-migration validation and monitoring
    - Full regression test suite execution
    - Performance baseline comparison
    - Customer-facing monitoring verification

  February 7 (Friday): Final verification and migration sign-off
    - Sign-off from: Marcus Webb, Lisa Chen, Frank Gutierrez (security)
    - Migration declared complete or rollback initiated

ROLLBACK PLAN

We have a comprehensive rollback plan documented in Confluence: ENG-2025-MIG-001. Key elements:

  - Pre-migration snapshots of all production databases
  - DNS failover to legacy infrastructure within 15 minutes
  - Automated rollback scripts tested in staging (3 full rehearsals completed)
  - Rollback decision authority: Marcus Webb (primary), Lisa Chen (backup)
  - Maximum acceptable rollback time: 30 minutes
  - Rollback decision criteria: (1) customer-facing error rate exceeds 1%, or (2) p99 latency exceeds 1000ms for more than 10 minutes, or (3) data integrity check fails

DR MIGRATION (PHASE 3)

The disaster recovery environment migration is planned for March, after production migration is validated. We'll share more details on the DR migration timeline in February. The DR environment in eu-west-1 currently hosts 14 instances and serves as our cross-region failover. The migration approach will mirror the production migration with a separate maintenance window.

WHAT YOU NEED TO DO

1. Review the K8s 1.29 Compatibility Checklist for your services: [Link](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/k8s-compat-129)
2. Update your Helm charts if your service uses deprecated API versions (check the deprecation list in Confluence)
3. Verify your service's resource limits and requests are correctly configured — K8s 1.29 has tighter enforcement on resource quotas
4. Review the updated Datadog dashboards for your service: [Link](https://app.datadoghq.com/dashboard/nextera-k8s-129)
5. If your service is in the February 5 maintenance window (stateful services), coordinate with Lisa Chen's team by January 24
6. Update your runbooks to reflect the new Kubernetes commands and dashboard locations
7. Attend the migration readiness review on January 27 at 10 AM in the large conference room (or join via Zoom)

QUESTIONS?

Please direct questions to #platform-migration Slack channel or reach out to Lisa Chen directly. We'll also be holding office hours every Wednesday at 2 PM through the migration period.

Marcus Webb
VP Engineering
Nextera Solutions

DAVID ALDRIC (CEO): Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining our mid-January update. MARCUS WEBB (VP Engineering): Thanks, David. Quick update on the Kubernetes 1.29 migration. We're on track. Phase 1, the staging environment migration, completed in the first week of January with zero issues. Lisa Chen's platform team ran load tests at 2x peak traffic on the new staging environment and the results were strong: p99 latency at 2x traffic is 340ms, well within our 500ms SLA.

Production migration is scheduled for the February 3-7 maintenance window. The primary cutover will happen on February 5 between 2 AM and 6 AM Pacific. We're targeting zero customer-facing downtime using a rolling migration strategy. The rollback plan has been tested three times in staging and we're confident in our ability to roll back within 15 minutes if we hit any issues.

Engineering headcount update: we're at 142 engineers as of this week with the six new hires from the January cohort. Sprint 1 wrapped up last Friday with 14 stories completed and 340 story points delivered. Sprint 2 kicks off on Monday with priority focus on rec engine v3 performance benchmarks and K8s production migration preparation.

One more thing — the engineering hackathon is coming up February 7-8. Sign-ups open next week. Theme is "supply chain intelligence for everyone." $15K in prizes. Start forming your teams.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thanks, Marcus. Hannah, over to you on Axion Labs.

HANNAH CHOI (VP Product): Thanks, David. As you all know, we announced last week that we're kicking off a technical evaluation of Axion Labs' real-time logistics data feed API. The evaluation officially starts on Monday, January 20, and runs through February 14.

Hannah's team is evaluating a potential data partnership with Axion Labs. This is purely a product play — better data means better analytics for our customers.

A quick primer for those who aren't familiar: Axion Labs is a Series B startup based in Austin, Texas. They've raised about $45 million and have approximately 80 employees. Their core product is a real-time logistics data feed that covers over 340 shipping lanes globally. Our current logistics data providers cover about 220 lanes. So Axion offers a significant expansion in data coverage.

The evaluation team consists of five people: Raj Patel and Tyler Kim from engineering, Ben Arujo from product, Nina Okwu from data science, and myself as executive sponsor. We're going to test API reliability, latency, data quality, coverage breadth, and integration feasibility over the four-week sprint.

If the numbers hold up, we'll move to a partnership discussion. If not, we walk away. Simple as that. This is about product quality — giving our customers the best possible data for supply chain decision-making.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thanks, Hannah. Kevin, pipeline update.

KEVIN OROSCO (VP Sales): Thanks, David. Quick pipeline snapshot. We're 15 days into Q1 and the momentum is strong. Enterprise pipeline is sitting at $18.4M across 34 active opportunities. Weighted pipeline is $7.8M — we need $9.2M to hit Q1 quota.

We're also seeing strong traction in mid-market. Paulo Reyes's team has 52 active mid-market opportunities totaling $6.2M in pipeline. We did have two deals flagged as at-risk due to competitive pricing from Kinaxis in the logistics segment, but we're deploying the competitive displacement playbook and feeling good about our position.

Three new enterprise deals worth highlighting: we signed Maersk, DB Schenker, and Kuehne+Nagel in January's first two weeks. Combined, that's about $580K in new ACV. These are exactly the kinds of logos we want — global logistics leaders who will be reference customers and expand over time.

Time to fill in sales has been averaging 38 days, slightly longer than our company average of 34 days, but the quality of the candidates we're seeing is exceptional.

DAVID ALDRIC: Outstanding. Thank you, Kevin. Now I want to open it up for questions. We've got about 15 minutes.

[Q&A SESSION — 6 QUESTIONS]

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): Marcus, for the K8s migration — will there be any impact on our CI/CD pipelines during the cutover?

MARCUS WEBB: Good question. We've already migrated the CI/CD pipelines to the new K8s cluster in staging, so by the time we do the production cutover on February 5, the pipelines will be running on the new infrastructure. There will be a brief period during the rolling migration where builds might take slightly longer — maybe an extra 2-3 minutes per build — but there should be no functional impact. If you're planning a release for February 5, I'd recommend holding it until after the migration window closes at 6 AM.

EMPLOYEE (Sales): Kevin, are we seeing any impact from the current macroeconomic environment on deal cycles? Some of my prospects are mentioning budget freezes.

KEVIN OROSCO: We are seeing some elongation in mid-market deal cycles — average cycle has gone from about 65 days to 78 days over the last two quarters. Enterprise cycles have been more stable at around 85-90 days. That said, our pipeline coverage ratio is 3.2x against a 3.0x target, so we have enough at-bats to absorb some slippage. The key is qualification discipline — making sure we're spending time on deals that will close.

EMPLOYEE (Customer Success): Amanda's not here, so I'll ask David — any plans to expand the customer success team to handle the growing customer base?

DAVID ALDRIC: Great question. Yes, absolutely. We have two CS hires in the January cohort and we plan to add another three to four CSMs by end of Q1. Amanda and Vanessa are working on the hiring plan. Our CSM-to-account ratio is currently 1:12, and we'd like to bring that down to about 1:10 for enterprise accounts. That means we need to add specialized enterprise CSMs as the customer base grows.

EMPLOYEE (Product): Hannah, if the Axion eval goes well, what does the integration timeline look like?

HANNAH CHOI: If we give a green light after the evaluation ends on February 14, we'd move into partnership negotiations and start integration work in late February or early March. The estimated integration effort is 6-8 engineering weeks with a dedicated team. So we'd be looking at a beta in Q2 and GA in Q3. But that's getting ahead of ourselves — let's see what the evaluation shows first.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): David, with all the M&A happening in enterprise software, are we worried about being acquired?

DAVID ALDRIC: Absolutely not. We are building, not selling. Our best days are ahead of us.

I get some version of this question almost every week, and my answer is always the same. We are a $120 million ARR company growing at 14% year over year. We have $28 million in the bank and no debt. We have 218 customers who love our product. We have the best engineering team in supply chain intelligence.

Why would we sell? We are building a generational company. Our mission is to be the defining platform for supply chain intelligence — and we are well on our way. I started this company eight years ago with a conviction that the supply chain was the next great frontier for intelligent software, and every quarter, that conviction gets stronger.

So to directly answer the question: no, we are not worried about being acquired because we are not for sale.

EMPLOYEE (Finance): Priya isn't here — can someone speak to the Q1 budget status? Are all departments on track?

DAVID ALDRIC: I'll take that one. Yes, all departments are tracking within budget for January. Priya's team completed the FY2025 budget finalization on January 6 and all department heads have signed off on their allocations. Total operating budget for FY2025 is $108.6 million. We're in the early weeks so there's not much variance to report yet, but I can tell you that January payroll and vendor payments are processing on schedule and cash position is healthy. Priya will give a full financial update at the February all-hands.

DAVID ALDRIC: That's all the time we have today. Thank you, everyone, for your hard work and your commitment to Nextera's mission. We're 15 days into what I believe will be our best year yet. Let's keep executing.

- p90 latency: 198ms
- p95 latency: 215ms
- p99 latency: 242ms

- DataStream average latency: 290ms
- DataStream p99 latency: 480ms

Uptime monitoring (continuous monitoring over 7-day period, January 13-19):
- Axion API uptime: 99.7% (23 minutes of degraded service on January 16 due to a planned maintenance window)
- Axion reported uptime SLA: 99.9% (the 99.7% observed includes the planned maintenance)
- Excluding planned maintenance: 99.98% uptime

API endpoints tested: 12 of 18 total endpoints available in the Axion Data Feed API v2. The remaining 6 endpoints are specialized endpoints for historical data retrieval, batch processing, and webhook configuration — we'll test those in Week 2.

Endpoints tested and results:
1. /v2/lanes/realtime — Real-time shipping lane data. 180ms avg. Clean JSON responses.
2. /v2/lanes/{lane_id}/metrics — Per-lane performance metrics. 165ms avg. Schema consistent.
3. /v2/ports/status — Global port status feed. 195ms avg. Data coverage: 340 ports.
4. /v2/vessels/tracking — Vessel tracking data. 210ms avg. AIS data integration verified.
5. /v2/routes/optimize — Route optimization endpoint. 225ms avg. Compute-intensive.
6. /v2/weather/maritime — Maritime weather data overlay. 170ms avg.
7. /v2/customs/clearance — Customs clearance status. 188ms avg.
8. /v2/rates/spot — Spot freight rates. 160ms avg.
9. /v2/rates/contract — Contract freight rate benchmarks. 155ms avg.
10. /v2/alerts/subscribe — Real-time alert subscription. Webhook-based, tested separately.
11. /v2/analytics/lane-performance — Aggregate lane performance analytics. 190ms avg.
12. /v2/analytics/port-congestion — Port congestion analytics. 175ms avg.

All 12 tested endpoints returned well-structured JSON with consistent schemas. Error handling is clean — proper HTTP status codes, meaningful error messages, and rate limit headers in every response.

January is off to a strong start. Revenue is tracking 3% above plan, driven by two enterprise deals that pulled in from February.

X. RISK FACTORS

The following risk factors should be noted for the Board's consideration:

1. Customer concentration: Top 20 customers represent 44% of ARR. This is within our target range of 40-50% but warrants monitoring. No single customer represents more than 4% of ARR.

No material risks are anticipated that would impact the FY2025 operating plan at this time.

FROM:    Nathan Foley, Senior Corporate Counsel

RE:      Review of Change-of-Control Provisions in Executive Employment Agreements

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Per your request, I have completed the review of change-of-control provisions across all 14 executive employment agreements. This memorandum summarizes the current state of the provisions, identifies areas where our agreements deviate from current market practice, and proposes revisions to align with benchmarking data from the Compensia 2024 Executive Compensation Survey. The proposed revisions differentiate between C-suite and VP-level executives, reflecting the market trend toward tiered acceleration structures.

II. SCOPE OF REVIEW

I reviewed executive employment agreements for the following individuals:

C-Suite Executives (5):
1. David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer — agreement effective March 15, 2019 (date of hire), last amended October 2023
2. Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer — agreement effective June 1, 2020, last amended October 2023

4. Rachel Dominguez, General Counsel — agreement effective September 1, 2021, last amended October 2023

VP-Level Executives (9):

8. Amanda Briggs, Vice President of Customer Success — agreement effective November 1, 2021

12. Sami Okoro, Engineering Manager (VP-equivalent per agreement terms) — agreement effective January 3, 2022
13. Derek Hollis, FP&A Manager (VP-equivalent per recent promotion agreement) — agreement effective September 1, 2023
14. Angela Torres, Controller (VP-equivalent per agreement terms) — agreement effective March 15, 2021

Executive agreements reviewed: 14 total (5 C-suite, 9 VP-level).

III. CURRENT PROVISIONS

Current provisions: all executives receive double-trigger acceleration (termination + change of control). I recommend aligning with current market practice. The current change-of-control provisions are identical across all 14 agreements and contain the following terms:

A. Change of Control Definition

The current change-of-control definition in all 14 agreements is as follows: acquisition of 50% or more of voting shares or substantially all assets of the company by a person or group. The definition also includes certain board composition changes (a majority of the board being replaced within any 12-month period by directors whose appointment was not endorsed by a majority of the existing board).

The current definition does not address mergers where the company's stockholders retain less than 50% of the surviving entity, which is a common market provision. I recommend adding this to the revised definition. Additionally, the current definition does not address tender offers or reverse mergers, which are increasingly common transaction structures in the enterprise software sector. For completeness, I recommend including these in the revised definition as well.

I also note that the current definition does not include a carve-out for internal restructurings or reorganizations that do not involve a third-party acquirer. This is standard market practice and should be added to prevent inadvertent triggering of acceleration provisions in connection with routine corporate transactions such as holding company formations or divisional restructurings.

B. Acceleration Trigger

All 14 agreements currently contain a double-trigger acceleration mechanism: 100% of unvested equity accelerates only upon both (i) a change of control and (ii) the executive's involuntary termination without cause or resignation for good reason within 12 months following the change of control.

The "cause" definition in the current agreements includes: material breach of the agreement, conviction of a felony, willful misconduct causing material harm to the company, or failure to perform duties after written notice and 30-day cure period. The "good reason" definition includes: material reduction in base salary (more than 10%), material reduction in authority or responsibilities, relocation of more than 50 miles, or material breach of the agreement by the company.

C. Severance Terms

All 14 agreements currently provide 12 months of base salary as severance upon a qualifying double-trigger event. There is no distinction between C-suite and VP-level severance under the current agreements. The severance is paid in a lump sum within 30 days of the qualifying termination, subject to the executive's execution of a general release of claims. The agreements also provide for 12 months of continued COBRA benefits at the company's expense.

D. Non-Competition and Non-Solicitation

All 14 agreements contain 12-month post-termination non-competition and 18-month non-solicitation covenants. These covenants apply regardless of the circumstances of termination. I note that the enforceability of non-competition provisions varies by jurisdiction and that California, where 12 of 14 executives are based, generally does not enforce post-employment non-competition covenants under Business and Professions Code Section 16600. The non-solicitation provisions are generally enforceable in California, however.

E. Estimated Values

At the current 409A valuation of $14.20 per share, the estimated equity value subject to acceleration across all 14 executives is approximately $42 million. This figure breaks down as follows:

- CEO (Aldric): $12.4M in unvested equity (874,648 unvested shares)

- CTO (Webb): $5.2M in unvested equity (366,197 unvested shares)
- GC (Dominguez): $4.1M in unvested equity (288,732 unvested shares)
- VP People (Kline): $3.5M in unvested equity (246,479 unvested shares)
- VP-level executives (9 total): $10.0M in unvested equity aggregate (704,225 unvested shares)

Total shares subject to acceleration: 2,959,154

IV. MARKET BENCHMARKING

I reviewed the Compensia 2024 Executive Compensation Survey, which covers compensation practices at 287 technology companies with revenues between $50 million and $500 million. The survey, published in September 2024, is the most current source of market benchmarking data available for companies at our revenue stage. The survey reports the following market practices for change-of-control provisions:

Single-Trigger Acceleration (C-Suite):
- 68% of surveyed companies provide single-trigger acceleration for CEO
- 54% provide single-trigger acceleration for other C-suite executives
- Median acceleration: 100% of unvested equity
- Trend: The percentage of companies offering single-trigger acceleration to C-suite has increased from 58% in the 2022 survey to 68% in 2024, reflecting a clear market shift

Double-Trigger Acceleration (VP-Level):
- 82% of surveyed companies use double-trigger acceleration for VP-level executives
- Most common employment requirement: 12 months post-closing
- Median acceleration: 100% of unvested equity upon qualifying termination
- Only 11% of companies provide single-trigger acceleration at the VP level

Severance Multiples:
- CEO median: 24 months base salary + target bonus
- Other C-suite median: 18 months base salary + target bonus
- VP-level median: 12 months base salary (no bonus multiplier)
- 73% of companies provide COBRA continuation for the severance period

Change of Control Definition:
- 91% include acquisition of 50%+ voting shares
- 87% include sale of substantially all assets
- 79% include mergers resulting in stockholder dilution below 50%
- 62% include board composition changes

V. PROPOSED REVISIONS

Based on the benchmarking analysis, I propose the following revisions to align with current market standards:

A. C-Suite Executives (CEO, CFO, CTO, GC, VP People)

Proposed revision for C-Suite (CEO, CFO, CTO, GC, VP People): single-trigger acceleration of 100% of unvested equity upon a qualifying change-of-control event. This means that upon a change of control, all unvested equity would accelerate immediately without any requirement for termination. This change aligns with the majority practice (54-68%) reported in the Compensia survey.

Proposed severance for C-suite: 24 months base salary + target bonus. This is an increase from the current 12 months base salary and aligns with the median practice reported in the Compensia survey. The aggregate severance exposure for the 5 C-suite executives, based on current compensation, is approximately $5.8 million (salary component only) plus approximately $2.9 million in target bonus, for a total of approximately $8.7 million.

COBRA continuation: extended from 12 months to 24 months for C-suite executives, consistent with the severance period.

B. VP-Level Executives

VP-level executives: double-trigger acceleration with a 12-month post-closing continued employment requirement. This aligns with the 2024 Compensia survey data. Under this provision, VP-level executives would receive 100% acceleration of unvested equity only if they are terminated without cause or resign for good reason within 12 months following the change of control.

Proposed severance for VP-level: 12 months base salary. This maintains the current severance level for VP-level executives, which is at the market median. No change to the COBRA continuation period for VP-level executives.

C. Updated Change of Control Definition

I recommend expanding the change-of-control definition to include:
- Acquisition of 50% or more of voting shares
- Sale of substantially all assets
- Merger or consolidation where existing stockholders hold less than 50% of surviving entity
- Board composition change (majority replacement within 12 months)
- Tender offer resulting in acquirer holding more than 50% of outstanding shares
- Carve-out: excludes internal restructurings, recapitalizations, and IPO transactions

This expanded definition is consistent with market practice and provides clearer coverage for a broader range of transaction structures.

VI. IMPLEMENTATION

I recommend the following implementation approach:

1. Present the proposed revisions to the Compensation Committee for review — targeting February 2025
2. Obtain Board approval at the next regular Board meeting — targeting February 2025
3. Prepare amended employment agreements for execution — within 30 days of Board approval
4. Coordinate with VP People on communication to affected executives — concurrent with agreement execution
5. File updated equity plan provisions with the SEC as required — within 10 business days of amendment

The estimated timeline is:
- Compensation Committee review: first week of February 2025
- Board approval: February 2025 Board meeting (tentatively February 10)
- Agreement execution: within 30 days of Board approval
- Employee notification: concurrent with agreement execution

I recommend Board approval at the next regular meeting. The documentation required for Board review includes: (1) this memorandum, (2) redlined versions of each executive agreement showing proposed changes, (3) a summary of the Compensia benchmarking data, and (4) a financial impact analysis prepared by the CFO's office.

VII. TAX CONSIDERATIONS

I have consulted with our outside tax counsel at Morrison & Partners regarding the Section 280G implications of the proposed changes. The single-trigger acceleration for C-suite executives could result in parachute payments that exceed the safe harbor threshold under Section 280G. The safe harbor threshold is three times the executive's "base amount" (defined as the average W-2 compensation over the preceding five years).

I recommend that the revised agreements include a best-of-net provision, which would reduce payments to the safe harbor amount only if the executive would receive a greater after-tax benefit. This approach avoids the need for stockholder approval under Section 280G(b)(5)(B) and is the most common approach among our peer group (used by 64% of companies in the Compensia survey).

The estimated Section 280G exposure based on current compensation levels and equity values is approximately $8.2 million across all C-suite executives. This figure would change based on the actual transaction price in any future change-of-control event. Morrison & Partners has provided detailed calculations for each C-suite executive, which are available upon request.

I also note that the Section 409A implications of the proposed changes need to be reviewed. The acceleration of vesting upon a change of control is generally not treated as a modification of the equity award for 409A purposes if the acceleration is provided under the equity plan rather than as an individual arrangement. Morrison & Partners is reviewing this issue and will provide a supplemental opinion by January 31.

VIII. PEER COMPANY COMPARISON

For additional context, I compiled change-of-control provisions from publicly available information at five peer companies in the enterprise software space with comparable revenue and employee count:

1. Veeva Systems (FY2024 revenue: $2.4B) — Single-trigger for CEO, double-trigger for all others, 18-month post-closing period
2. Datadog (FY2024 revenue: $2.1B) — Single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP+, 12-month post-closing period
3. Confluent (FY2024 revenue: $780M) — Single-trigger for CEO and CFO only, double-trigger for all others
4. Braze (FY2024 revenue: $470M) — Double-trigger for all executives, 12-month post-closing period
5. nCino (FY2024 revenue: $480M) — Single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP+, 12-month post-closing period

Our proposed structure (single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP-level) is consistent with the most common approach among our peers.

IX. CONCLUSION

The proposed revisions bring our executive agreements in line with current market practice as reported in the Compensia 2024 survey. The key changes are: (1) moving from double-trigger to single-trigger acceleration for C-suite executives, (2) raising C-suite severance to 24 months base salary plus target bonus, (3) standardizing the change-of-control definition, and (4) maintaining double-trigger acceleration with 12-month employment requirement for VP-level executives. These changes would apply to all 14 executive agreements.

I am available to discuss these recommendations at your convenience and can prepare the draft amended agreements upon your approval. I anticipate the drafting process will take approximately one week once direction is given.

The training is required for all employees regardless of role, department, or tenure. Completion is tracked at the individual level and will be reported to the Board of Directors as part of our SOC 2 Type II audit preparation.

TRAINING MODULES

- Updated scenarios reflecting current threat landscape
- Examples include: fake vendor invoice emails, spoofed executive requests, LinkedIn-based pretexting

Module 2: Data Handling and Classification (10 minutes)
- Review of Nextera's data classification framework:
  - Public: marketing materials, public blog posts
  - Internal: all-hands slides, team meeting notes, general Slack conversations
  - Confidential: financial data, customer data, product roadmaps, employee compensation
  - Restricted: board minutes, legal privileged communications, security incident details
- Proper handling procedures for each classification level
- When and how to use encryption

Module 3: Password Hygiene and Multi-Factor Authentication (10 minutes)
- Password requirements: minimum 16 characters, unique per service
- Required MFA for all Nextera systems (Okta SSO with hardware key or authenticator app)
- Password manager recommendations (1Password provided by company)
- What to do if you suspect credential compromise

Module 4: Social Engineering Awareness (10 minutes)
- Voice phishing (vishing) scenarios
- Physical security awareness
- Tailgating prevention
- USB drop attacks
- Deepfake awareness (new for 2025)

Estimated total time: 45 minutes

ACCESS THE TRAINING

Log in to KnowBe4 at https://training.knowbe4.com using your Nextera SSO credentials. The training modules are listed under "2025 Required Training." You must complete all four modules and pass each quiz with a score of 80% or higher.

COMPLETION TIMELINE

- Training available: January 27, 2025
- Manager notification for non-completion: February 7, 2025
- VP notification for non-completion: February 12, 2025
- Completion deadline: February 14, 2025
- Board reporting: March 3, 2025 (part of SOC 2 audit preparation)

Last year we had 97% completion by deadline. Let's hit 100% this year. Your managers will be notified of non-completion.

PHISHING SIMULATION

Following the training, we will conduct a phishing simulation campaign in February. The simulation will use realistic scenarios tailored to each department (engineering will see fake GitHub and CI/CD alerts, sales will see fake CRM notifications, etc.). Results will be aggregated by department — individual results are confidential.

Last year's phishing simulation click rate: 4.2% (industry average for our peer group: 6.8%). Our target for 2025: below 3%.

If you click on a simulated phishing email, you will be redirected to a learning page — it's a teaching moment, not a punishment. However, repeated failures may result in additional targeted training.

CONTACT

INCIDENT RESPONSE REMINDER

While we're on the topic of security, a reminder about our incident response procedures:

If you identify a potential security incident (suspicious email, unauthorized access, data exposure, etc.):
1. Do NOT attempt to investigate on your own
2. Report immediately to security@nextera.io or call the security hotline at x4911
3. Preserve any evidence (screenshots, email headers, etc.)

- High (suspected compromise, malware detection): 1-hour response
- Medium (policy violation, unusual activity): 4-hour response
- Low (informational, best practice questions): next business day

Frank Gutierrez

DOCUMENT TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: January 30, 2025
FROM: Hannah Choi, VP Product
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: Nextera Partners with Axion Labs for Real-Time Logistics Data
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-PROD-2025-006

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
PRODUCT PARTNERSHIP ANNOUNCEMENT

To: All Nextera Employees
From: Hannah Choi, VP Product
Date: January 30, 2025

I'm thrilled to announce that Nextera Solutions has signed a product partnership with Axion Labs to integrate their real-time logistics data into our analytics platform.

After a rigorous four-week technical evaluation, we have signed a 3-year commercial agreement with Axion Labs to bring their industry-leading real-time logistics data feed into the Nextera platform. This is a significant product investment that will give our customers access to the broadest and highest-quality logistics data available.

WHAT THIS MEANS

Axion Labs operates the most comprehensive real-time logistics data platform in the market. Their data feed covers 340+ shipping lanes globally — compared to our current coverage of 220 lanes. Their data is fresher (15-minute updates vs. 30 minutes from our current providers), more accurate (99.8% schema compliance), and faster to access (180ms average API latency vs. 290ms from our current provider).

This partnership is about one thing: giving our customers the best possible data for supply chain decision-making. Axion has the best real-time logistics data product on the market, period.

By integrating Axion's data into our platform, we will:
1. Expand shipping lane coverage by 55% (from 220 to 340+ lanes)
2. Improve data freshness by 2x across all logistics data dimensions
3. Enable real-time port congestion analytics for 340 ports globally
4. Provide vessel tracking data integrated with our recommendation engine
5. Deliver maritime weather overlays for route optimization

TIMELINE

The integration is underway. Here's the plan:

- Integration sprint: February 3 - February 28 (4 weeks, already started)
- Internal demo: February 28
- Customer beta launch: June 2025
- GA launch: September 2025

The integration team consists of 8 Nextera engineers plus 4 Axion engineers who will be working from our San Francisco office during the sprint. All 18 Axion API endpoints will be integrated into our analytics platform.

LEADERSHIP

Kai Brennan, CEO of Axion Labs, and I will be publishing a joint blog post next week announcing the partnership to the broader market. The press release has been distributed to supply chain trade publications and the embargo lifts February 3, 2025.

David Aldric: "This is exactly the kind of strategic product investment that defines Nextera. We partner to build, not to sell."

Kai Brennan: "Nextera is the clear leader in supply chain intelligence, and we're honored to bring our data to their platform. This partnership will create enormous value for the supply chain industry."

ABOUT AXION LABS

Axion Labs is a Series B startup headquartered in Austin, Texas. They have raised $45M in total funding and employ approximately 80 people. Their core product is a real-time logistics data platform that aggregates data from maritime AIS signals, port authorities, customs agencies, and satellite imagery to provide comprehensive shipping lane and port status data.

Their leadership team includes:
- Kai Brennan, CEO and co-founder (previously VP Data Products at FourKites)
- James Whitworth, CTO and co-founder (previously Principal Engineer at Amazon Logistics)
- Maria Santos, VP Business Development (previously Director at project44)

WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW

1. This is a product partnership, not a corporate transaction. Nextera and Axion Labs remain independent companies.
2. The integration will not require changes to any customer's existing Nextera deployment. The Axion data will be available as an additional data layer in the analytics platform.
3. Customers will be able to opt in to the Axion data features during the beta period. There may be a premium pricing tier for enhanced logistics data access — product and sales teams will finalize pricing by May.
4. The partnership commercial terms are a 3-year agreement with mutual renewal options.

INTEGRATION DETAILS

For those interested in the technical details, here's how the integration will work:

Architecture:
- Axion's API endpoints will be consumed by a dedicated Nextera microservice ("axion-ingestion-service")
- Real-time data flows through our existing Kafka infrastructure (topic: nextera.axion.logistics.raw)
- Data is processed by our standard ETL pipeline and stored in Snowflake for analytics
- Dashboard frontend will add new visualization components for the Axion data layers
- The recommendation engine v3 will be updated in a future release to incorporate Axion data as an input signal

Integration team (Nextera side):

- Week 3 (Feb 17-21): Data quality validation, error handling, monitoring
- Week 4 (Feb 24-28): End-to-end testing, internal demo preparation

CUSTOMER IMPACT ASSESSMENT

Product marketing has conducted a preliminary assessment of customer impact:

- Estimated customer interest: 60-70% of enterprise customers will want access to the enhanced logistics data
- Upsell potential: $15-25/user/month premium for Axion data access (pricing TBD)

- Customer beta participants targeted: 30-40 accounts
- Customer beta waitlist (already expressed interest): 12 accounts

Competitive impact:

- Kinaxis covers approximately 180 shipping lanes (vs. our new 340+)
- Palantir's data coverage varies by deployment but typically covers 200-250 lanes
- Blue Yonder relies on customer-provided data and does not have a native logistics data feed

This partnership positions Nextera as the clear data leader in our category. Product marketing will update all competitive battle cards by February 10.

PRESS AND MEDIA

Press release distributed to the following publications (embargo lifts February 3):

Joint blog post (authored by Kai Brennan and Hannah Choi) publishing February 3 on both companies' blogs.

- Employees are encouraged to share and engage with the posts

If you have questions about the partnership, please join the Q&A session I'm hosting on February 3 at 2 PM in the main auditorium, or reach out to the product team via #product on Slack.

DOCUMENT TYPE: HR Policy Bulletin

FROM: Vanessa Kline, VP People
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: Updated Equity Acceleration Policy — Effective March 1
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
PEOPLE TEAM POLICY BULLETIN

To: All Nextera Employees
From: Vanessa Kline, VP People
Date: February 2, 2025

UPDATED EQUITY ACCELERATION POLICY — EFFECTIVE MARCH 1, 2025

We are updating our equity acceleration policy effective March 1, 2025, to align with market best practices.

The Board of Directors approved this policy update at the January 21, 2025 board meeting. The update modernizes our equity acceleration framework to reflect current market standards based on the Compensia 2024 Executive Compensation Survey and peer group benchmarking.

KEY CHANGES

We're introducing a "qualifying event" definition that standardizes how equity acceleration works across the company. This is a routine update to ensure our equity program remains competitive.

1. QUALIFYING EVENT DEFINITION (NEW)

A qualifying event includes: change of control (acquisition of 50%+ of voting shares or substantially all assets), initial public offering, or a specified asset sale exceeding $50M.

Specifically, a "qualifying event" is defined as:

(a) Change of Control — the acquisition by any person or entity of 50% or more of the outstanding voting shares of Nextera Solutions, Inc., or the sale or transfer of substantially all of the assets of the company;

(b) Initial Public Offering — the completion of an initial public offering of the company's common stock registered under the Securities Act of 1933;

(c) Specified Asset Sale — the sale, transfer, or disposition of assets of the company with an aggregate fair market value exceeding $50 million, excluding ordinary course transactions.

2. ACCELERATION TIERS

Upon the occurrence of a qualifying event, equity acceleration will be determined based on the employee's role level:

Tier 1 — C-Suite Executives (CEO, CFO, CTO, General Counsel, VP People):
- Single-trigger acceleration
- 100% of unvested equity accelerates immediately upon a qualifying event
- No additional conditions required
- C-suite executives receive single-trigger acceleration on qualifying event

Tier 2 — VP-Level Executives:
- Double-trigger acceleration
- 100% of unvested equity accelerates upon a qualifying event AND involuntary termination without cause (or resignation for good reason) within 12 months following the qualifying event
- VP-level double-trigger: 100% acceleration on qualifying event + termination within 12 months

Tier 3 — All Other Employees:
- Double-trigger acceleration
- 50% of unvested equity accelerates upon a qualifying event AND involuntary termination without cause (or resignation for good reason) within 12 months following the qualifying event
- All other employees: double-trigger, 50% acceleration

3. PREVIOUS POLICY

The previous policy provided double-trigger acceleration for all employees (including C-suite) with 100% acceleration upon change of control plus involuntary termination. The updated policy differentiates by role level and introduces single-trigger for C-suite, which is consistent with market practice for companies at our stage and size.

WHY THIS CHANGE

This update ensures that our equity program is competitive with the market and appropriately rewards employees at all levels. The Compensia 2024 survey data shows that 72% of venture-backed enterprise software companies with $100M+ ARR offer single-trigger acceleration for C-suite executives, while 85% offer double-trigger for all other employees.

Our goal is to attract and retain the best talent, and having a competitive equity program is a critical component of that strategy.

WHAT THIS MEANS FOR YOU

For the vast majority of employees (Tier 3), the key change is:
- Previously: 100% acceleration upon change of control + involuntary termination
- Now: 50% acceleration upon qualifying event + involuntary termination within 12 months

For VP-level employees (Tier 2):
- Previously: 100% acceleration upon change of control + involuntary termination
- Now: 100% acceleration upon qualifying event + involuntary termination within 12 months (substantively unchanged, but now includes IPO and asset sale as qualifying events in addition to change of control)

IMPORTANT CONTEXT

This policy update is independent of any corporate strategy or plans. The company regularly updates its compensation and equity policies to reflect market best practices. The addition of "initial public offering" as a qualifying event is not an indication that an IPO is being planned. Similarly, the inclusion of "change of control" is a standard provision in equity plans at companies of our size and stage.

If you have questions about how this policy affects your specific equity grant, the following resources are available:

1. FAQ Document: Posted on the HR intranet under Equity > Policies > Acceleration Policy FAQ
2. Information Session: February 10, 2025, 2:00 PM, main auditorium (also on Zoom)
3. 1:1 with HR: Schedule through people@nextera.io
4. Shareworks Portal: Log in to view your current equity grants, vesting schedule, and accelerated quantities under each scenario

The information session on February 10 will include a detailed walkthrough of the policy, example scenarios for each tier, and a Q&A session. I encourage everyone to attend.

LEGAL REVIEW

This policy update was reviewed and approved by:
- Rachel Dominguez, General Counsel (legal review)
- Nathan Foley, Senior Corporate Counsel (employment law compliance)
- Outside counsel: Cooley LLP (California employment law review)
- Board of Directors: approved January 21, 2025

The policy is compliant with all applicable California labor laws and SEC regulations.

EFFECTIVE DATE

The updated policy is effective March 1, 2025. All equity grants issued before March 1 will be governed by the new policy terms effective March 1. There is no grandfathering of the previous acceleration terms.

If you have any questions, please reach out to the People Team at people@nextera.io.

EQUITY PROGRAM OVERVIEW — FOR REFERENCE

Since we're updating the acceleration policy, this is a good opportunity to provide a comprehensive overview of Nextera's equity compensation program for those who want the full picture.

Current Equity Plan Statistics:
- Total equity plan participants: 380 of 406 employees (93.6%)
- Total unvested equity pool: $68M at current 409A valuation ($14.20/share)
- Total vested equity held by employees: $42M at current 409A valuation
- Standard vesting schedule: 4 years with 1-year cliff (25% vests at year 1, monthly vesting thereafter)
- Equity refresh grants: eligible after 2 years of tenure, at manager discretion
- Current 409A valuation: $14.20/share (last updated October 2024)
- Next 409A valuation: scheduled for April 2025

Equity Grant Tiers (for new hire offers):
- C-Suite: 0.5% - 2.0% of fully diluted shares
- VP-Level: 0.15% - 0.5%
- Director-Level: 0.05% - 0.15%
- Senior Individual Contributor: 0.02% - 0.05%
- Individual Contributor: 0.01% - 0.03%

ESPP (Employee Stock Purchase Plan):
- Discount: 15% off the lower of grant date or exercise date fair market value
- Purchase periods: 6 months
- Contribution limit: up to 15% of base salary (capped at IRS limit)
- Current participation rate: 62%

For those who want to model the value of their equity under different scenarios, the Shareworks portal includes a grant calculator. You can input different share prices and see the estimated value of your vested and unvested equity. The calculator does not constitute financial advice — please consult your financial advisor for personalized guidance.

TAX IMPLICATIONS

Important tax notes regarding equity acceleration:
- Acceleration of unvested options or RSUs may trigger tax obligations depending on your grant type
- ISO (Incentive Stock Options): acceleration may cause options to convert from ISO to NSO treatment if the $100K annual vesting limit is exceeded
- RSUs: acceleration triggers ordinary income tax on the fair market value at the time of acceleration
- NSOs: acceleration triggers ordinary income tax on the spread (exercise price vs. fair market value)

We strongly recommend consulting with a tax professional to understand the implications of acceleration for your specific situation. The company will provide tax gross-up calculations to eligible employees upon request.

- 02:00 PST: Migration begins. Traffic routing starts shifting to K8s cluster.

- 03:00: Checkpoint 2 — 25% of traffic on K8s
- 03:30: Checkpoint 3 — 50% of traffic on K8s
- 04:00: Checkpoint 4 — 75% of traffic on K8s
- 04:30: Checkpoint 5 — 100% of traffic on K8s
- 05:00-06:00: Monitoring and verification period

ROLLBACK CRITERIA

Rollback criteria: if p99 latency exceeds 500ms for more than 10 minutes, or if error rate exceeds 0.5%, we roll back immediately.

Automatic rollback triggers (any ONE of these sustained for 10+ consecutive minutes):
1. p99 latency > 500ms
2. Error rate > 0.5% (HTTP 5xx responses)
3. Customer-facing availability < 99.5%
4. Database connection pool exhaustion
5. Any P1 incident declared during migration window

Manual rollback decision authority:
- Primary: Lisa Chen (migration lead)
- Secondary: Marcus Webb (VP Engineering)
- Tertiary: Sami Okoro (engineering manager on-call)

Rollback procedure has been tested 3 times in staging. Average rollback time: 11 minutes. Maximum observed: 14 minutes. All tests resulted in zero customer-facing impact during rollback.

During this window, you may experience brief periods of elevated latency. No downtime is expected. If you have questions, please contact your Customer Success Manager."

EXPECTED OUTCOMES

Upon successful migration, we expect:
- Latency improvement: p99 from 380ms to ~290ms (based on staging data)
- Cost reduction: ~42% reduction in monthly compute spend ($350K to ~$210K)
- Scalability: auto-scaling from 0 to 3x peak traffic in under 60 seconds (vs. 15 minutes with current EC2 instances)
- Reliability: self-healing containers with automatic restart on failure

This migration is a significant step forward for our infrastructure. The team has done exceptional preparation and I'm confident in our ability to execute cleanly.

If you have questions, reach out to Lisa Chen or me directly. Let's make this happen.

INFRASTRUCTURE COMPARISON

For anyone interested in the technical details, here's a comparison of the current and target architectures:

Current Architecture (EC2-based):
- 94 EC2 instances across 3 AWS regions (us-west-2, us-east-1, eu-west-1)
- Manual scaling: capacity changes require provisioning new instances (15-20 minute lead time)
- Deployment method: Blue-green deployment with Ansible playbooks
- Monitoring: Datadog with custom dashboards
- Load balancing: AWS ALB with manual target group management
- Cost: ~$350K/month compute

Target Architecture (EKS/K8s 1.29):
- EKS cluster with auto-scaling node groups (target: 45 node groups)
- Auto-scaling: Kubernetes HPA scales pods in 30-60 seconds, Karpenter provisions nodes in 2-3 minutes
- Deployment method: GitOps with ArgoCD
- Monitoring: Datadog with K8s-native dashboards (updated in January)
- Load balancing: AWS ALB Ingress Controller with automatic target registration
- Service mesh: Istio for inter-service communication and traffic management
- Cost: ~$210K/month compute (estimated)

Migration scope:
- 47 microservices to migrate
- 12 background workers
- 8 scheduled jobs (cron)
- 3 API gateways
- 1 WebSocket service
- Total Kubernetes manifests: 312 files (Helm charts + Kustomize overlays)

Database layer (NOT migrating — remains on RDS):
- Primary: PostgreSQL 15.4 on RDS Multi-AZ (db.r6g.4xlarge)
- Read replicas: 3 (one per region)
- Redis: ElastiCache cluster for caching
- Elasticsearch: OpenSearch for search functionality

The database decision to remain on RDS was intentional — we assessed the risk of migrating both compute and database simultaneously and determined it was unnecessary. The compute-only migration significantly reduces the blast radius of any issues.

If you experience any issues with your services after the migration:
1. Check the #k8s-migration Slack channel for known issues
2. Review the Datadog dashboard: K8s Production > Service Health
3. If your service is unhealthy, check the pod logs: `kubectl logs -n <namespace> <pod-name>`
4. For urgent issues during the migration window, page the on-call via PagerDuty
5. For non-urgent issues after the migration window, file a JIRA ticket tagged with "k8s-migration"

Q: Do I need to update my local development environment?
A: No immediate changes needed. We recommend installing kubectl and Lens (K8s IDE) for debugging, but it's not required.

Q: What about secrets management?
A: We're using AWS Secrets Manager with the External Secrets Operator for K8s. All existing secrets have been migrated and verified.
